page.title: 08THE PLOUGH INN
page.content: The Plough at Pyecombe, which is over 3OO years old, is situated on the busy A23. Because of its situation it relies heavily on passing trade, about 7O% of the custom coming from these people. The villagers do use the pub but mainly between 7.3O pm and 9.OO pm. Approximately 334 gallons of beer are sold a week. The landlord, who took over in February 1985, lives in the pub and is a Sussex man. He employs 4 people, one of whom is responsible for the food he sells at lunchtimes. The Plough has no facilities for children. The Plough was once a coaching inn. The front wall is made of dressed flints. Inside it is divided into 2 bars with a back room for darts and eating. It has low wooden ceiling beams. The busiest times are between 9 and 11.3O pm.
